description: Work out Private Residence Relief when you sell your home, whether you need to pay Capital Gains Tax (CGT) and what proportion of your gain you pay tax on

details.body:
Use this tool to find out:

  • if you need to pay tax when you sell (or ‘dispose of’) your home
  • how to work out how much Private Residence Relief you get

What counts as your home

You must have lived in your home as your only or main residence at some point while you owned it.

If you’re married or in a civil partnership only one home per couple counts as your main residence at any one time.

When you don’t get relief

You don’t get tax relief if you bought it just to make a gain.

If you or your home are overseas

You may get relief if the property is in the UK, but you’re not a UK resident.

From 6 April 2015, you must spend at least 90 days in an overseas property to qualify for relief for that tax year.

nodes.body: Answer ‘yes’ if you owned more than one home at any point while you owned the home you’re selling.
nodes.title: Do you own more than one home?
Are the grounds of your home bigger than 5,000 square metres, including the buildings?

nodes.body:
Don’t include:

  • the first 12 months you owned your home if it was being built, renovated or you couldn’t sell your previous home
  • the last 9 months before selling your home (36 months if you’re disabled, in long-term residential care or you sold the property before 6 April 2014)

Also don’t include time you lived away from home for:

  • any reason for periods adding up to 3 years
  • work in the UK for up to 4 years
  • work outside the UK for any period

You normally need to live in your home again afterwards, unless your job means you can’t go back.

If you’re not UK resident for tax

From 6 April 2015, if you spend fewer than 90 days in your home in a tax year, you count as having lived away for that year.
nodes.title: Have you lived away from your home?

nodes.body: Don’t count using a spare room occasionally as an office or having a single lodger.
nodes.title: Have you let out any part of your home or used any part exclusively for business?

nodes.body: You can read the rules about nominating your home.
nodes.title: Has the property you're selling been nominated as your main home for the entire time you've owned it?
Are the grounds of the home you're selling bigger than 5,000 square metres, including the buildings?
Are the grounds of the home you're selling bigger than 5,000 square metres including the buildings?

Don’t include:

  • the first 12 months you owned your home if it was being built, renovated or you couldn’t sell your previous home
  • the last 9 months before selling your home

Also don’t include time you lived away from home for:

  • any reason for periods adding up to 3 years
  • work in the UK for up to 4 years
  • work outside the UK for any period

You normally need to live in your home again afterwards, unless your job means you can’t go back.

If you’re not UK resident for tax

From 6 April 2015, if you spend fewer than 90 days in your home in a tax year, you count as having lived away for that year.

nodes.title: Have you lived away from your nominated home?

nodes.body:
Don’t include:

  • the first 12 months you owned your home if it was being built, renovated or you couldn’t sell your previous home
  • the last 9 months before selling your home (36 months if you’re disabled, in long-term residential care or you sold the property before 6 April 2014)

Also don’t include time you lived away from home for:

  • any reason for periods adding up to 3 years
  • work in the UK for up to 4 years
  • work outside the UK for any period

You normally need to live in your home again afterwards, unless your job means you can’t go back.

If you’re not UK resident for tax

From 6 April 2015, if you spend fewer than 90 days in your home in a tax year, you count as having lived away for that year.

nodes.body: Don’t count using a spare room occasionally as an office or having a single lodger.
nodes.title: Have you let out any part of your home or used any part exclusively for business?

nodes.body:
You don’t need to pay any tax on the gain you make when you sell your home.

You don’t need to contact HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) or fill in the Capital Gains Tax part of your tax return unless:

  • you’ve made a gain on another asset
  • you’re not UK resident

Keep a copy of this page for your records.

If you’re not sure about any of the answers you’ve given, call the Capital Gains Tax helpline.
nodes.title: You’re entitled to full Private Residence Relief

nodes.body:
You need to work out what proportion of your gain you get relief on.

Your calculation will be complex because there are several things that affect your relief. Find out how to get help with working out your tax.

What affects your relief

The relief you get when you sell your property is affected by:

  • what you used it for
  • its size

What you used it for

If you never lived in the part of your home you let out or used only for business you don’t get any relief on that part.

If at any time you did, you’ll get relief for:

  • the last 9 months you owned the property
  • any time you didn’t let it out or use it for business

You may get Letting Relief if you let out part of your home.

The size of your property

Because your grounds are bigger than 5,000 square metres you may not get relief for the whole area. Page 5 of the HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) Private Residence Relief guide explains the rules.

What to do next

There are other rules that may affect the amount of Capital Gains Tax you pay. Work out if you need to pay.
nodes.title: You're entitled to some Private Residence Relief

nodes.body:
Because your grounds are bigger than 5,000 square metres you may not get relief for the whole area. Page 5 of the HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) Private Residence Relief guide explains the rules.

Before you work out the relief you get you must work out your gain.

Find out how to get help with working out your tax.

What to do next

There are other rules that may affect the amount of Capital Gains Tax you pay. Work out if you need to pay.
nodes.title: You're entitled to some Private Residence Relief

nodes.body:
You need to work out what proportion of your gain you get relief on.

Your calculation will be complex because there are several things that affect your relief. Find out how to get help with working out your tax.

What affects your relief

The relief you get when you sell your property is affected by:

  • when you lived there
  • what you used it for
  • its size

When you lived there

In most cases, you only get relief for one home for any period. You must work out when you lived in your property as your main home.

If you’re married or in a civil partnership only one home per couple counts as your main home at any one time.

If you’ve nominated a home you can’t get relief for another property for the time your home is nominated, apart from for certain periods that always qualify for relief.

What you used it for

If you never lived in the part of your home you let out or used only for business you don’t get any relief on that part.

If at any time you did, you’ll get relief for:

  • the last 9 months you owned the property
  • any time you didn’t let it out or use it for business

You may get Letting Relief if you let out part of your home.

The size of your property

Because the grounds of the home you’re selling are bigger than 5,000 square metres you may not get relief for the whole area. Page 5 of the HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) Private Residence Relief guide explains the rules.

What to do next

There are other rules that may affect the amount of Capital Gains Tax you pay. Work out if you need to pay.
nodes.title: You're entitled to some Private Residence Relief

nodes.body:
You need to work out what proportion of your gain you get relief on.

Your calculation will be complex because there are several things that affect your relief. Find out how to get help with working out your tax.

What affects your relief

The relief you get when you sell your property is affected by:

  • when you lived there
  • its size

When you lived there

In most cases, you only get relief for one home for any period. You must work out when you lived in your property as your main home.

If you’re married or in a civil partnership only one home per couple counts as your main home at any one time.

If you’ve nominated a home you can’t get relief for another property for the time your home is nominated, apart from for certain periods that always qualify for relief.

You always get relief for the last 9 months you own a property.

The size of your property

Because the grounds of the home you’re selling are bigger than 5,000 square metres you may not get relief for the whole area. Page 5 of the HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) Private Residence Relief guide explains the rules.

What to do next

There are other rules that may affect the amount of Capital Gains Tax you pay. Work out if you need to pay.
nodes.title: You're entitled to some Private Residence Relief

nodes.body:
You need to work out what proportion of your gain you get relief on.

Your calculation will be complex because there are several things that affect your relief. Find out how to get help with working out your tax.

What affects your relief

The relief you get when you sell your property is affected by:

  • when you lived there
  • what you used it for

When you lived there

In most cases, you only get relief for one home for any period. You must work out when you lived in your property as your main home.

If you’re married or in a civil partnership only one home per couple counts as your main home at any one time.

If you’ve nominated a home you can’t get relief for another property for the time your home is nominated, apart from for certain periods that always qualify for relief.

What you used it for

If you never lived in the part of your home you let out or used only for business you don’t get any relief on that part.

If at any time you did, you’ll get relief for:

  • the last 9 months you owned the property
  • any time you didn’t let it out or use it for business

You may get Letting Relief if you let out part of your home.

Example You sell your home and make a gain of £100,000.

You owned the property for 20 years but you lived in another home for 5 (25% of the time). The time you lived away wasn’t during the last 9 months or another period that qualified for relief. This means the amount you get relief on is reduced by 25% (25% of £100,000, which is £25,000). You get relief on £75,000.

The home you’re selling has 10 rooms. You used one room (10% of your home) exclusively for business for 2 years (10% of the period you owned it). The time you used it for business wasn’t during the last 9 months you owned the property. This means the amount you get relief on (£75,000) is reduced by a further 1% (10% of 10%). You get relief on 99% of £75,000, which is £74,250.

What to do next

There are other rules that may affect the amount of Capital Gains Tax you pay. Work out if you need to pay.

nodes.body:

Find out how to get help with working out your tax.

Example You sell your home and make a gain of £100,000.

You owned the property for 20 years but you lived in another home for 5 (25% of the time). The time you lived away wasn’t during the last 9 months or another period that qualified for relief. This means the amount you get relief on is reduced by 25% (25% of £100,000, which is £25,000).

You get relief on £75,000.

nodes.body:
You need to work out what proportion of your gain you get relief on.

Your calculation will be complex because there are several things that affect your relief. Find out how to get help with working out your tax.

  • its size

The time you lived away

You don’t get relief for the time you lived away from your home, apart from for certain periods.

What you used it for

If at any time you did, you get relief for the time you didn’t let it out or use it for business. You’ll also get relief for the last 9 months you owned the property. This is extended to 36 months if:

  • you’re in long-term residential care
  • you sold it before 6 April 2014

  • the time you lived away
  • its size

The time you lived away

You don’t get relief for the time you lived away from your home, apart from for certain periods.

nodes.body:
You don’t get relief for the time you lived away from your home, apart from for certain periods. You always get relief for absences in the last 9 months.

If you’re disabled, in long-term residential care or you sold the property before 6 April 2014 you always get relief for the last 36 months.

Before you work out your relief you must work out your gain.

Find out how to get help with working out your tax.

Example You sell your home and make a gain of £100,000.

You owned your home for 20 years and lived away for 5 (25% of the time). The time you lived away wasn’t during the last 9 months or another period that qualified for relief. This means the amount you get relief on is reduced by 25% (25% of £100,000, which is £25,000).

nodes.title: You're entitled to some Private Residence Relief

nodes.body:
If you never lived in the part of your home you let out or used only for business you don’t get any relief on that part.

If at any time you did, you get relief for the time you didn’t let it out or use it for business. You’ll also get relief for the last 9 months you owned the property. This is extended to 36 months if:

  • you’re disabled
  • you’re in long-term residential care
  • you sold it before 6 April 2014

You may get Letting Relief if you let out part of your home.

Before you work out the relief you get you must work out your gain.

Find out how to get help with working out your tax.

Example You sell your home and make a gain of £100,000. You owned your home for 10 years.

You used one room in your 10-room home (10% of your home) exclusively for business for one year (10% of the period you owned it). The time you used it for business wasn’t during the last 9 months you owned the property. This means the amount of relief you get is reduced by 1% (10% of 10%).

You get relief on £99,000.

What to do next

There are other rules that may affect the amount of Capital Gains Tax you pay. Work out if you need to pay.

Your calculation will be complex because there are several things that affect your relief. Find out how to get help with working out your tax.

nodes.title: You're entitled to some Private Residence Relief

nodes.body:
You need to work out what proportion of your gain you get relief on.

Your calculation will be complex because there are several things that affect your relief. Find out how to get help with working out your tax.

What affects your relief

The relief you get when you sell your property is affected by:

  • the time you lived away
  • what you used it for

The time you lived away

You don’t get relief for the time you lived away from your home, apart from for certain periods.

What you used it for

If you never lived in the part of your home you let out or used only for business you don’t get any relief on that part.

If at any time you did, you’ll get relief for:

  • the last 9 months you owned the property
  • any time you didn’t let it out or use it for business

You may get Letting Relief if you let out part of your home.

Example You sell your home and make a gain of £100,000. You owned your home for 10 years.

You used one room in your 10-room home (10% of your home) exclusively for business for one year (10% of the period you owned it). The time you used it for business wasn’t during the last 9 months you owned the property. This means the amount of relief you get is reduced by 1% (10% of 10%). You get relief on £99,000.

You didn’t live in your home for 5 of the 10 years (50% of the time you owned the property). The time you lived away wasn’t during the last 9 months or another period that qualified for relief. This means the amount of gain you get relief on (£99,000) is reduced by 50%.

The total amount you get relief on is £49,500.

What to do next

There are other rules that may affect the amount of Capital Gains Tax you pay. Work out if you need to pay.
nodes.title: You're entitled to some Private Residence Relief

nodes.body:
If you never lived in the part of your home you let out or used only for business you don’t get any relief on that part.

If at any time you did, you’ll get relief for:

  • the last 9 months you owned the property
  • any time you didn’t let it out or use it for business

You may get Letting Relief if you let out part of your home.

Before you work out the relief you get you must work out your gain.

Find out how to get help with working out your tax.

Example You sell your home and make a gain of £100,000. You lived in your home for 10 years.

You used one room in your 10-room home (10% of your home) exclusively for business for one year (10% of the period you owned it). The time you used it for business wasn’t during the last 9 months you owned the property. This means the amount of relief you get is reduced by 1% (10% of 10%).

You get relief on £99,000.

What to do next

There are other rules that may affect the amount of Capital Gains Tax you pay. Work out if you need to pay.
nodes.title: You're entitled to some Private Residence Relief

nodes.body:
You don’t get relief for the time you lived away from your home, apart from for certain periods. You always get relief for absences in the last 9 months.

Before you work out the relief you get you must work out your gain.

Find out how to get help with working out your tax.

Example You sell your home and make a gain of £100,000. You owned your home for 10 years.

You didn’t live in your home for 5 of the 10 years (50% of the time you owned the property). The time you lived away wasn’t during the last 9 months or another period that qualified for relief. This means the amount of gain you get relief on (£100,000) is reduced by 50%.

The total amount you get relief on is £50,000.

What to do next

There are other rules that may affect the amount of Capital Gains Tax you pay. Work out if you need to pay.
nodes.title: You're entitled to some Private Residence Relief

nodes.body:
You don’t need to pay any tax on the gain you make when you sell your nominated home.

You don’t need to contact HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC) or fill in the Capital Gains Tax part of your tax return, unless:

  • you’ve made a gain on another asset
  • you’re not UK resident

Keep a copy of this page for your records.

You need to pay Capital Gains Tax if you sell a home you didn’t nominate.

If you’re not sure about any of the answers you’ve given, call the Capital Gains Tax helpline.
